articles.title: Predictions
articles.summary: This document, titled "Predictions," details the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) upcoming events for October and November 1979. It lists various general meetings featuring speakers on topics such as the Pioneer 11 Saturn encounter and 400" telescope design, board meetings, and numerous outdoor and indoor star parties, including a Halloween costume party. Key astronomical dates like full and new moons are also noted for each month.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The article summarizes a highly active astronomical September, featuring a lunar eclipse and numerous star parties, and previews an eventful October for the club. Key upcoming activities include a significant general meeting with a NASA speaker on Pioneer 11 and a book dedication, along with a Halloween party, and social news like a wedding announcement. It also covers club updates, observing tips for cold weather and solar activity, and volunteer requests.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article provides updates on several comets, noting that Comet Bradfield (1979c) has become significantly fainter than predicted, while Periodic Comet Schwassmann-Wachmann 3 (1979g) was successfully recovered after being unobserved since 1930. It also details the recent discoveries of Comet Kowal (1979h) by a professional astronomer and Comet Meier (1979i) by an amateur, highlighting unusual aspects of Kowal's discovery nearly a year after its closest approach to the sun and the comet labeling convention.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBER'S CORNER
articles.summary: This article from SJAA's 'Member's Corner' spotlights two members: Chris Pratt, an enthusiast in telescope making and astrophotography, and Robert Hatcher, a young member passionate about observational astronomy heading to UC Berkeley. It also includes an observing report from a well-attended SJAA star party at Henry Coe State Park, detailing various observations, equipment used, and interesting events like Pete Manly being stung by a bee and a clear view of M57's central star.

articles.title: AANC/NASA-Ames Joint Conference on Astronomy
articles.summary: The AANC/NASA-Ames Joint Conference on Astronomy, held Sept. 15-16 at Ames Research Center, was a highly successful event featuring professional talks on planetary astronomy and diverse presentations by amateur astronomers. Key topics included the Sun, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, film hypersensitizing, and nebular filters. The conference also celebrated achievements with Messier Club awards and the AANC's amateur achievement award for Don Machholz, and was notable for turning away 100 attendees due to popularity.

articles.title: Sanborn Canyon Star Party—August 25, 1979
articles.summary: Attendees of the Sanborn Canyon Star Party on August 25, 1979, gathered for an evening of stargazing and camaraderie. Despite rapid cooling and city light interference, they observed objects like the Ring Nebula, M13, and the Omega Nebula, even providing an impromptu astronomy lesson to curious police officers. The event concluded with late-night food and storytelling at a local restaurant.

articles.title: A Full Moon at Loma Prieta
articles.summary: About twenty people gathered at Loma Prieta to observe a lunar eclipse. During the event, they socialized, set up equipment, and took various photographs of the eclipse, with some trying creative techniques like multiple exposures. Post-eclipse, the group continued their festivities at a local restaurant before heading home.

articles.title: Eliminating Subjectivity in Zonal Testing
articles.summary: This article proposes a novel, objective method for zonal testing of astronomical mirrors, aiming to eliminate the subjectivity inherent in interpreting shadow edges. It introduces a "pin stick" technique that utilizes the "on-off diffraction effect" – the instantaneous illumination of a pin silhouette – to precisely define the knife-edge position for various zones or "concentric mirrors." This method allows for repeatable measurements, even when shadows are indistinct, thereby providing a more accurate assessment of mirror quality.

articles.title: The Constellations
articles.summary: This article, 'The Constellations' by Doug Buettner, presents a challenge to readers to test their knowledge of the autumn sky. It features a list of scrambled constellation names and some bright stars, tasking participants with unscrambling them. The answers to this celestial puzzle are promised in the next month's edition.

articles.title: Mailing list: Additions, subtractions, and corrections
articles.summary: This document outlines various updates to a mailing list, including the addition of new members like Charles Chew and Jeff Owen. It also lists new phone numbers for Ron Cunha and Walt Schoendorf, alongside several address changes for existing members such as Brian Day, Geerge Cook, and John Clement, ensuring the contact information remains current.

articles.title: The Rosicrucian Planetarium and Science Museum
articles.summary: The Rosicrucian Planetarium and Science Museum is hosting a free public lecture titled "PROJECT PIONEER-SATURN" on Saturday, October 6, 1979. Dr. John H. Wolfe from NASA Ames Research Center will discuss the preliminary scientific findings of Pioneer 11's recent Saturn flyby, summarizing its five-year mission and new discoveries about the planet. This event, co-sponsored with the San Jose Astronomical Association, will take place at 7:30 p.m. in the Francis Bacon Auditorium in San Jose.
